August 9, 2012

Update to the Feed

Hi Everyone! So I deleted the old feed and created a new one. Why? The old one had ads on it back when I believed in “monetizing” everything (I was so stupid). The problem was, I couldn’t delete the ads anymore. I had done some type of intricate who-knows-what and was now stuck. The only way out was to delete the feed and start fresh so that’s what I did. You can now subscribe to the new feed here or with the RSS link above. As always, thanks for reading!

August 6, 2012

The East Wing Gets a RefreshLink to Post

Today I've launched version three of The East Wing theme. I'm excited. I'm excited not only because of the new design (tons of improvements have been made), I'm also excited because of the great attention the show has received and the people that it's helped. When I first started the show, I wanted to learn from people who are much smarter than me. I wanted to find out whatever information I could get so that I could improve. I've learned a lot in the last six months and I'm finally on the way to becoming the designer I want to be.

It makes me happy to see how people have really enjoyed the show. Personally, I've always had a love for broadcasting so this show was a perfect merge of two great passions of mine: broadcasting and design. Even if no one would've ever listened, I would've continued on but, I can't explain how amazing it is to see that the show helps people with their work and inspires them.

The East Wing has some very exciting times on the horizon. I've gotten into a good grove and people enjoy the guests we talk to. If you haven't already, I invite you to listen to the show and take a peek at the new design. I hope it makes the experience better for you when listening and looking for episodes. Thank you from the bottom of my heart for your support.

July 26, 2012

.net Magazine: Mike Monteiro on Handling ClientsLink to Post

When I walk into a pitch I have no idea how to solve a client’s problem, but I’m confident that I have a process for figuring it out. It’s the process that you pitch. Not the solution.

This is such an awesome answer. I feel like we can be quick to give or offer solutions to problems when we haven't actually done the research. As designers, we need to stick to our process and make sure it's in place in every project we work on. It's the only way we can truly solve problems.

July 23, 2012

New Art Directed Article on WireframingLink to Post

Wireframing without a design brief can be assimilated to taking a calculus test without actually taking the class. Sure, you can do without but, you don’t have the necessary information to know what problems to solve and how to solve them.

I've been working on an article about wireframing and the design process and was finally able to finish it and post it. It resides at my new art directed site, timlikestowrite.com. You should check it out!

July 10, 2012

Tim Likes To WriteLink to Post

The site is called Tim Likes To Write and it’s truer now more than ever. The truth is we should all be finding time to write and put our thoughts down on paper (whether it’s done literally or figuratively).

I launched a new site! I'm not one to launch new sites often so this is really exciting for me. It'll be the place where I put longer thoughts and more thought out articles. Also, you might see guest writers from time to time. I hope you like the new site and I look forward to hearing your feedback!

Update: This site no longer exists.

July 5, 2012

I Put Comments on My Site

Yup. That's right. I put comments on here. I'm actually kind of excited about it. Jason Van Lue wrote a great small post the other day on writing. He's a new guy I've been following after his great talk at the Front-End Design Conference. The part I found especially interesting was this:

In this digital age not only is it incredibly easy to put the proverbial pen to paper, but the barrier for ‘acceptable’ writing is much lower. It’s a time where 140 characters is the norm, so don’t hesitate just because you’re not the ‘best writer’.

For me, that's always been what stops me. There are a myriad of more talented and skilled writers than me. Hell, they could probably express what I'm thinking better than my own self. Yet, I've seen that writing is therapeutic and in fact, gets me to delve deeper into topics and really think about them on another level.

Anyway, this is a really long way of saying that as you've noticed, I'm writing more here and hope you'll join in on the conversation. I also want to take this opportunity to urge you to write. Our industry thrives because there are always people willing to share what they learn and I hope you're having a part in that too.

June 25, 2012

My Move to Minnesota

This past week, I started a new era in my life. I finally made my move to the beautiful Land of 10,000 Lakes: Minnesota. Some of you who know me will remember that I've been here before. You're right! About two years ago (has it been that long?) I spent six months here and fell in love with the city and people. I had the chance to make some great friends and meet very creative people who are working on awesome things.

At the moment, I'm busy getting things setup and put away. It's crazy how much there is do to when you move. I've moved plenty of times so, naturally, I thought I'd be a pro. What I found out, is that nothing prepares you for a cross-country move. I will say though, what really helped out was this post by Allison House. If you're making a big move, I really recommend you read it. It'll help you get organized and, really, for a move like this, that's the most important thing.

Anyway, now that I'm in Minnesota, I'm hoping to find a web design meetup to go to. If you have any suggestions, let me know! I also want to take this moment to give a huge thanks to Lullabot for being awesome and letting me move and work wherever I want. The East Wing will be ramping up again this week with Ethan Marcotte. It's going to be a great episode!

As always, thanks for reading! I'll see y'all on the internets!

June 1, 2012

Article on Designing “in the Browser”Link to Post

As web designers, we work in a vibrant industry filled with lots of ideas and many who are great at voicing strong opinions. At least for me, it's easy to get sucked into trying to get everything right and wind up focusing on the wrong things.[...] if you want to be a great web designer, focusing on the specific tools you use within your workflow is really not that helpful. Rather, focusing on how to uncover problems, how to understand users, how the technology of your medium works, how to discover and emulate beauty, and how to enjoy your work are going to be far more beneficial to your long term success! Jared Ponchot

I love this section from Jared's newest article. Really, his whole article on designing in the browser is spectacular and brings up some thought-provoking points. This is quite the hot topic in the industry at the moment and if you listen to The East Wing, you know I've voiced my opinion on this quite a few times. However, Jared does a great job in re-focusing all of us. He's right. The tools we use aren't what matters. At the end of the day, our effectiveness in discovering and solving problems within our work is what matters. It's a great read, I really recommend you check it out.

May 30, 2012

The State of Instagram

Many people have been talking about Instagram lately, especially with the introduction of Facebook Camera. My pal, Adelle Charles wrote about it on her blog and she brings up some interesting points. I was also reading a new review of the app on iPhone Appstorm with the title being: Instagram is Reborn as Facebook Camera.

I am on my knees, begging that this isn't accurate. It's funny how worked up we can get over a simple app but, that's just it. It's not just an app. These companies become part of how we do things everyday and we live in a society where these more successful startups (Facebook, Twitter and Google) seem to be buying everything.

Y'all remember Tweetie? Remember how absolutely beautiful it was? Remember how it was the best Twitter client and pioneered UI patterns that are still in use today? Then Twitter came in, bought it and eventually it became the crap it is today.

I fear the same is happening to Instagram. I will gladly give you of my hard earned money if you make something awesome. In this case, I would've gladly payed for Instagram (This is the guy that downloaded the completely leaked Drake album and proceeded to pay for it when it came out a week later). I genuinely care for people that make things I like and if I could've had a part in Instagram not becoming part of Facebook's massive monopoly, that would've made me happy.

To those of you who are entrepreneurs and making new apps, charge from the beginning. If you make something of value, people will pay for it.

May 29, 2012

New Leaked iPhone 5 Pictures!Link to Post

Two separate iPhone part suppliers have leaked nearly identical-looking versions of what appears to be a backplate for Apple’s next iPhone, both of which support rumors of the device’s lengthened body and redesigned dock connector.

This is so exciting! I’m really looking forward to the release of the iPhone 5. I’m really happy about the larger screen size. However, I do have to say I’m a bit disappointed that the dock connector has been redesigned. If that turns out to be true, I think it’ll be a headache. A lot of us have multiple Apple products and up until now, they awesomely share the same charger. What do you think? Are you excited about the new iPhone?

May 24, 2012

Pro Designers have their say on FacebookLink to Post

Personally, I’d love to get my hands on the Facebook UX and UI. There’s so many things I feel could be improved upon, but I’m sure they stay the same because they work towards the intended goals and purposes of Facebook very well.

Some of the top designers reside at Facebook at the moment so there must be solid reasoning behind why elements work the way they do... Sarah Parmenter

I really liked this post on the Creative Bloq and I love Sarah's answer. The truth is, it's so easy to go around saying that an interface could be more polished. Personally, I'd love to see the amazing that Sarah would do with Facebook (would it be pink?). I, like most people, am not really happy with what's been happening with the Facebook UI. However, as Sarah points out, no one knows better than the designers that actually work there what the goals and purposes are behind the design decisions. In my humble opinion, that might be something we don't always agree with but must respect.

May 24, 2012

The Real Reasons You’re Working So Hard...Link to Post

More than 31% of college-educated male workers are regularly logging 50 or more hours a week at work, up from 22% in 1980. Forty percent of American adults get less than seven hours of sleep on weekdays, reports the National Sleep Foundation, up from 31% in 2001. Bloomberg Business Week

I was doing research for a talk I'll be giving in June titled, Work to Live, Don't Live to Work, and I found these statistics very interesting. To tell you the truth, it doesn't surprise me in the least. The fact of the matter is this: There are only 24 hours in a day and if you're using more hours for work, what more important things are you missing out on? The full article has a wealth of information and if you're in the San Diego area, you should come see my presentation!

May 22, 2012

New Beginnings

So as you may have noticed the site got a bit of a refresh. I've been working diligently on the new Lullabot.com and I was inspired to rethink my own site. I decided to finally treat my site as I would a client site (for the most part). Create a type of creative brief, wireframe key pages, and pay attention to the details of the site (i.e. textures, hover effects and, yes, an adaptive layout).

There were many things that bothered me about the old site and I've done my best to address them. Mostly, I had a problem with not only the display of content but, the creation of it as well. I'm the type to find interesting links all the time and often have small pieces I'd like to share. This design will make that easy. My pal Galen, helped me create a post format for links. I'm so thankful for his help.

My larger pieces, however, will mostly live on the Lullabot blog. I'm so happy to be working there and I'm excited to be playing a role in the design team and in creating design related content together with my awesome teammate Jared Ponchot. With that said, if I think of something that doesn't fit there, it will always have a home here.

As always, I'd appreciate any feedback and constructive criticism that you might have about the site. Thanks for reading and your continued support.

May 14, 2012

Constructive CriticismLink to Post

We're at a time where technology is moving a lot faster than we can sometimes design for. That means we'll make mistakes. We'll have content that we don't know how to deliver on every device.

I wrote my first article on the Lullabot Blog! It's on Constructive Criticism. I find that this trend to publicly shame people about the work they're doing is wrong and isn't the way to make the web a better place. It's a quick read; something small you can digest during a break in your work day. Hope you enjoy!

March 12, 2012

Having Fun and Be Happy

There's no need to sacrifice happiness for success. We believe that happiness, fun, and general silliness bring with them an energy which fuels creativity and innovation, creates a more open and communicative workplace, and makes for a more productive, more dedicated team. It's also just more fun. We try to focus on the positive and downplay competition and negativism. We are grateful for our successes and celebrate them. Lullabot Core Values

Isn't that awesome? I love the sound of that and I'm so happy and excited to now be working with Lullabot. Lullabot is the world's top Drupal consulting and education company. They're responsible for creating websites for the Grammy's, Martha Stewart, WWE and more.

This means I'm no longer working at WorkSimple and I'd like to take this time to thank the wonderful people there, for the opportunity to work with them. I learned so much from the team and I can't wait to see the great things they're in the process of releasing.

I'll also be attending my first conference: DrupalCon Denver! I'll be tweeting and checking in like crazy and if you'll be there, let me know! I'd love to meet ya!

As always, thank you for reading and your support! I'm excited about this new opportunity at Lullabot and look forward to the projects I'll be working on.

February 22, 2012

On Podcasting

Wanted to create a quick screencast that goes over the basics on setting up Podpress, a plugin for Wordpress that is made for podcasting. We go through creating a feed, running it through feedburner and submitting to the iTunes store. Hope you find this useful!
